content: The "Declaration of Official Language Act of 1997" establishes English as the official language of the government. The "Declaration of Official Language Act of 1997" establishes English as the official language of the United States government and promotes its use for communication among citizens. The "Declaration of Official Language Act of 1997" establishes English as the official language of the United States government and promotes its use for communication among citizens. Duties of citizenship include encouraging all citizens to read, write, and speak English. Naturalization requirements emphasize fluency in English as essential for full citizenship, with ceremonies conducted solely in English. Exceptions are made for religious purposes. The "Declaration of Official Language Act of 1997" establishes English as the official language for religious purposes, training in foreign languages, and use of non-English terms in government documents. It preempts any inconsistent State or Federal laws, is not intended to affect foreign language learning programs in schools, and allows for civil action in case of violations. Repeals Title VII of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, excluding sections 7201 through 7309. Repeal of bilingual voting requirements. Repeals bilingual election requirements under Section 203 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 and amends Section 4 by removing subsection (f). Conforming amendments eliminate references to Section 203 and Section 4 in various sections of the Voting Rights Act of 1965. The text chunk discusses amendments to Section 4 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965, specifically removing references to guarantees in subsection (f)(2) related to voting rights violations in states or subdivisions.
